headline: Up 17% in 2025, Has Warren Buffett-Led Berkshire Hathaway Run Up Too Far, Too Fast?
summary: Berkshire Hathaway (NYSE: BRK.A) (NYSE: BRK.B) is up 17% year to date (YTD) at the time of this writing -- handily crushing an 8.3% decline in the S&P 500 (SNPINDEX: ^GSPC).  Berkshire Hathaway has been on such a tear that it is one of the top 40 best-performing S&P 500 components in 2025.  Hovering around an all-time high, Berkshire's market cap is now $1.15 trillion -- making it the sixth-most valuable U.S. company behind Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL), Microsoft, Nvidia, Amazon, Alphabet, and Meta Platforms.

headline: Apple (NasdaqGS:AAPL) Dips 14% In One Week As Trade Tensions Impact Market
summary: Apple (NasdaqGS:AAPL) recently integrated CONNEQT Health's arterial biomarkers into its Health app, marking a significant step towards enhancing health management capabilities. Despite this development, Apple's stock dropped 14% over the past week. This decline aligned with broader market turbulence, as the Nasdaq entered bear market territory amid escalating tariff tensions between the U.S. and China, leading to significant declines in major indexes, such as the Dow dropping 2,200 points...

headline: Think You Know Apple? Here's 1 Lesser-Known Fact You Shouldn't Overlook.
summary: With a market capitalization of just under $3 trillion, Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) holds the title of the world's most valuable company.  Given all that, nearly every investor will be familiar with Apple.  Apple generated $391 billion in sales in its fiscal 2024 (which ended Sept. 28).

headline: 2 No-Brainer Artificial Intelligence (AI) Stocks Owned by Warren Buffett Right Now
summary: Most people don't think of these companies as AI businesses, but when you dig deeper, few companies stand to benefit as much from the AI revolution as these two Buffett stocks.  Few companies are as directly exposed to rising demand for AI than Amazon (NASDAQ: AMZN).  To understand why this is, zoom out and look at how the AI industry functions.

headline: Some iPhone Users Upgrade, Fearing Tariff-Induced Price Hike
summary: It’s too early to say whether tariffs that whacked Apple’s share price last week will result in an iPhone price increase, but some customers aren’t waiting to find out.  Sales associates at two Apple stores in San Francisco on Saturday said some customers mentioned the tariffs as their reason for buying new iPhones.  May Lee, a San Francisco resident, said she was already planning to buy a new iPhone in the near term, but decided to purchase it now, ahead of any potential tariffs-related price hikes.
